But even though Dylan Jr. released two largely acoustic sets under his own name since, this continuation (letÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not label it a comeback) reunites the singer/songwriter with co-founder/keyboardist Rami Jaffee and long time bassist Greg Richling for another go-round of lyrically challenging, tightly produced and played roots rock and roll.

The younger Dylan has admitted that the solo troubadour thing was only a career side road and being the frontman of a touring band remains his first love. Judging from these impressive results, he has picked up where he left off five years ago with an album that fits seamlessly into the WallflowersÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ existing five disc catalog. Despite the recent promotional blitz, a change of label from Interscope to Columbia and a not particularly indicative single that sounds like a pretty good Clash B-side, little has altered in the WallflowersÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ basic sonic template. DylanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s grainy croon remains instantly recognizable. But DylanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s talent for matching, smart plentiful (arguably too much so) words to chiming melodies supported by a solid, unpretentious rock band and sung with conviction has returned.

Unlike other backing outfits like the E Street Band or PettyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Heartbreakers, the largely faceless Wallflowers donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t have an identifiable sound. Guitarist Stuart Mathis gets few chances to strut whatever stuff he might have in DylanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s tightly constructed songs, only two of which break the four minute mark. Dylan remains the star of the show, spitting out sharp, somewhat obtuse lyrics that push rockers like the opening Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hospital for SinnersÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ and the following Ã¢â‚¬Å“Misfits and Lovers,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ the latter a zippy track with a singalong chorus and a rhythm that borrows from Ã¢â‚¬Å“This is Radio ClashÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s insistent backbeat.

It makes this new material reminiscent of everything that has come before.
